item.content:encoded:
It may be counting chickens, but if the godaddy forwarding kicks in within the next few hours fortheloveofgoditsmascarpone.com will be the internet’s most recent “Single Serving Site“.

I’m rusty, rusty but in the last 72 minutes to starting to write this post:

  1. Registered fortheloveofgoditsmascarpone.com at godaddy.com
  2. Realized they have less free things than they used to
  3. Forwarded it to http://machaggis.net/fortheloveofgoditsmascarpone.com (still to kick in at this instant) with framing
  4. Registered for AdWords, realized its the wrong thing
  5. Registered for AdSense, have a sneaking suspicion I may have done this before years ago, get told to wait two or three days
  6. Hacked up (with too much google love) the index.html page
  7. Messed around with fonts, styles, underlines and margins
  8. CVS my launch files (all one of them: index.html)
  9. Upload to http://machaggis.net/fortheloveofgoditsmascarpone.com (use this link if the forwarding isn’t working yet)
  10. Comment on Danika’s single serving site Facebook post with cross-advertising for: fortheloveofgoditsmascarpone.com
  11. Write this blog post
  12. Re-edit this blog post with bolds for all the non-linked domain names
  13. Retire to richness, fame, and internet-geekery. I could have been unpacking I guess.

Good night.

Update: And then we fiddle again and smartquote the main page – the lack of curly quotes was quite unsightly.

item.content:encoded:
And when I say hacked, I mean machaggis.net, planetdanika, bluefacedpixie, ringraziamento – the whole bally machaggis.net real estate. Files changed, php inserted with DATA expanding doobry, index.html changed. Awful.

So it’s all blown away, clean redeploy from the initial January deploy on this ISP, passwords changed, MD5 cronjob installed, users disabled on the blogs…. and we’ll see.

I haven’t yet resolved to upgrade WP (hopelessly out of date that it is) because frankly I think this was some other hack. But it could have been an old WP php hole, so I will probably upgrade in the future. It’s just going to be so much work (uncustomizing the templates, reworking plugins etc) as opposed to this rather brute force method, and I’m still busy at work and have the girls back to play with, and have missed so much summer due to the House already that… bugger it… if the MD5’s hold, the old WP stays!

Yup, somewhere along the line I’ve been hacked.

I’ve let the robotic logins slide for waaay too long, relying on the math plugin to prevent comment spam, but somewhere my decrepit, embarrassingly old, installation of WordPress has been goosed.

So, sometime in the near future we will go offline and I will attempt to rectify the hackery. Even though I should be either mountain biking or working on the house. Damn, and I’m taking this Friday off too.

item.content:encoded:
Re-treading old ground, perhaps, but we’ve been unavailable some sometime today and I bet you didn’t notice.

In the world of geek, machaggis.net moved hosting providers.

We left luxsci.com and moved to sustainablewebsites.com.

What this means for machaggis.net:

  • no top page on machaggis.net as I’ve only moved the blogs
  • the blogs are all working (tell me if they are not)
  • new email systems (but our email addresses are the same)

For the occasional reader, it should mean nothing is different (perhaps a re-flush of RSS feeds, perhaps a lost email in a very small window today).

Luxsci was fine, but a little more serious and industrial strength than our little family website needed and now we’re wind-powered, eco-friendly and have oodles of more stuff for less money. C’est la vie.

Welcome to the New Year.

I bailed on Accelerando after slogging at it for a couple of eternities (having a sabbatical for Last Light of the Sun in the process). I started Wee Free Men with a joy that can only come of light hearted Terry Pratchett-expectation. It was a solid TP, without being great. Apparently the follow-up to this particular book (TP has about 100 books in Discworld and about) is even better (A Hat Full of Sky).
For the curious, The Wee Free Men in this particular book were the inspiration of the bluefacedpixie name.
Accelerando: 1/5
The Wee Free Men: 3/5
The Last Light Of The Sun: 3/5

item.content:encoded:
Well, it had to happen. I’ve been spending time fixing spam issues on some of my little websites and have also ran into an email spam problem.

First of all, the website issues. From the turn of the year I noticed a large spike in comment spam hitting ballardcornerspark.org. This isn’t really that surprising – its a public website, we broadcast the address, and the @ballardcornerspark.org email addresses get hosed all the time. I cranked out google and found a couple of nice plugins for WordPress 2 that I installed and the problem disappeared (so far!). Basically a simple math question to post a comment and also a tool to close old posts from comments.

And then a few days ago, bluefacedpixie started to get hit too (mostly from one bad IP address that I could block) at least 2 comments an hour. The cutting edge of fame – my Ridgid post was spotlighted at Signal vs. Noise which probably led robots to find the bfp blog – my own little version of being slashdotted (and my bandwidth use did jump too…). I started to get repetitive strain injury with the whole “mark all as spam” comment moderation so tonight added a couple of additions along the same lines to bluefacedpixie. The same Math Comment Spam Plugin as used on ballardcornerspark, but I used a simpler Comment Shutoff because this blog is older with a more hacked installation of WordPress (note to self: someday take the time to upgrade to WordPress 2).

I’ll let you know how they do – by the time I finish this post I will have missed a few timeslots for new spam to arrive.

If successful then I suppose the rest of the family (planetdanika, premodernist and Ringraziamento) will all need the same treatment.

And now we get to the sad tale of my email address and other people’s computers. A few weeks ago I sent out Lucy’s birth announcement to what we could conservatively call half the English-speaking world. Mostly using email addresses provided by D. As D was busy that day I sent out the email: to self, bcc known universe, from me. Ooops.

Since that day I’ve been getting hit by email spam much more than normal: Spam Assassin is failing at my host provider, Apple Mail’s pretty-crappy Junk filter fails to catch them and my carefully crafted “smack it dead unless it’s sent to me” filter also fails. Mostly stock market spam, very well done most of it too. My only assumption is that some of the recipients of the birth email are hacked/spambotted/virused and my very visible “from” email address is now on more spammers sell lists that previously. Bugger. I should have used a more temporary email address, but we so wanted those replies.

If you received the Lucy announcement and read this blog, and people you email complain about all the spam they get – you might want to run a little “clean my computer” magic on the old Windows box.

No spam so far, I’m going to bed.

item.content:encoded:
I’ve indirectly mentioned Ballard Corners Park before, in a photo per day in June.

It’s now time, however, to throw my hat (and heart) in the ring and do the full on “nothing-comes-for-free-in-America-isn’t-neighbourhood-fund-raising-a-great-thing” thing.

I live in Ballard (inballard, wikipedia), it’s a nice little community but by a freak of its past it’s short of green spaces i.e. parks.

A few blocks from our house there are two lots that are being re-purposed for a neighbourhood park under the Green Spaces/Pro Parks Levy. Politics aside, we hope to build (in 2008) a child-friendly park that can act as a locus for the local families. Ballard is so short of parks that the open area built beside the public library as part of a corporate “we want to build condos on top of our grocery store” deal is frequented by children in the summer (ok, the fountains help).

The working title for this project is Ballard Corners Park and the committee is called Friends of Ballards Corners Park. More details can be found at the main website at http://ballardcornerspark.org. I say the working name of the park is “Ballard Corners” only because the final name is decided by the Seattle Parks dept. and will probably be named after a dead councillor’s wife or Bill Gates’ dog. But that’s not really the point.

The park costs upwards of $400,000. Yup, $400,000. Not cheap but it looks good. And a significant portion of the money has to be raised through fund-raising, sponsorship and “matching”.

Although not part of the committee I’ve been helping out in whatever way I can. Danika and I have attended a few meetings and banked a few volunteer hours. Danika has planted bulbs in the rain to pretty-up our wasteland lot for the spring. I’ve helped out on the pending t-shirts. And I’m helping raise money from friends and family by skimming affiliate money for a good cause from internet shopping monsters such as Amazon.com.

So if you’re about to shop at Amazon.com to buy Danika a 30th birthday present (hint, hint) or Thanksgiving or the pending holidays. Don’t just shop at Amazon. Shop at Amazon by using this link, or going to ballardcornerspark.org/shop (where hopefully over time more than Amazon will be featured), or access the Ballard Corners Park Amazon Store.

This method gives upwards of 4% of revenue to the funds, and you can bet every little helps. We’re also working with local companies (such as Elephants Gerald for t-shirts) so this represents an ability for non-locals to help the community Danika and I live in.

And you’re going to see links appear both on bluefacedpixie.com and planetdanika.com in the near future (once I recover from a Mac wipe that has set me back weeks in terms of technology). item.content:encoded:
…but if you jump over to planetdanika using Safari (on a Mac) then the header “planetdanika” has a nice shadow to it. This makes it stand out when the white header is on a bright photo background. A lovely touch brought about with this one line:

#header { text-shadow: #111111 0.1em 0.1em 0.2em }

There’s more though:

It took 2 minutes to add this, and it looked so nice I did the same up top to bluefacedpixie. However this story skips the part where I spent a good couple of hours wrestling with making a drop shadow that worked in browsers other than Safari – because IE and Firefox don’t support the CSS3 text-shadow.

Most googling brought me to some CSS that looked like this:

.shadowMe, .shadowMe span { position: relative; margin: 0; padding: 20px; text-align: right;}
span.shadow {position: absolute; text-align: right; padding: 0, 0, -20px, 0; }
span.shadow {
top: 1px;
left: 1px;
color: #777777;
}

and accompanying use of class and span in the markup where I wanted the shadow. I couldn’t get it to work and right adjust the header, mostly due to my lack of CSS-fu. As I didn’t want to flip all of the images in planetdanika’s header files to put her on the right I have currently abandoned this approach and left the sites Safari-only-friendly.

It annoys me when simple things are simple, and then don’t work, and the workarounds suck so much time and fiddling. Mmm.
